subject: RE: [junit] Why no assertNotEquals()?
msgSnippet: That means that: - You ll get a fail if they re equal - You ll get a fail if they re unequal (because the assertEquals() fails!) But it shouldn t be hard to
messageBody:
That means that:

- You'll get a fail if they're equal
- You'll get a fail if they're unequal (because the assertEquals() fails!)

But it shouldn't be hard to code anyways, doing the equals and conditional
fail() and making up a message with the toString()...

--Tim

-----Original Message-----
From: Bill de hÓra [mailto:dehora@...]
Sent: woensdag 25 juni 2003 17:00
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Why no assertNotEquals()?


J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> No good reason. It just wasn't built.
>
> The solution is to roll your own or use a standard extension like
JUnit-addons. If Vladimir doesn't have it, then bug him to add it.

Add a fail() after assertEquals():

public void assertNotEquals(msg, ...)
{
assertEquals(msg, ..);
fail(msg);
}

Bill de hÓra
